issues.description: Conflicting instructions about the SealSaloon.stock field: the problem text tells students to initialize both attributes (orders and stock) in the SealSaloon constructor (problem_statement.md, lines ~70–71), but it also requires that the stock attribute be static (shared across all instances) (problem_statement.md, lines ~77–81). In Java a static final field must be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer, not in an instance constructor. This mismatch can confuse students and lead to compile-time errors if they try to follow both instructions literally. The reference solution resolves this by declaring and initializing stock as a static final field at declaration (SealSaloon.java, lines 5–6), which contradicts the earlier instruction to initialize it in the constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the instructions consistent: either (A) keep stock as a static (shared) attribute and instruct students to initialize it at declaration or in a static initializer (remove the instruction to initialize stock in the instance constructor); or (B) keep the instruction to initialize stock in the constructor and remove the requirement that stock be static. Prefer (A) to match the intended shared-stock design and the provided solution: update the problem statement to say explicitly that "stock is static (shared) and should be initialized at declaration (or in a static initializer), while orders should be initialized in the constructor." Also update the UML/diagrams (if shown) to indicate that stock is static if desired.
